description.text:
A quick corner protector for glass shelving (or your head against the corner....)
Designed in Alibre PE (CAD), I have included seven thicknesses:
4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10mm.
I'm in metric land so if you need an imperial version and have a copy of Alibre just edit the extrusion labelled 'glass thickness' to your requirement.

• Load the STL into your chosen print software.
  • Align to print as you require (when I have time I'll realign these in Netfabb and re-save them)
  • Print it!

  • Push fit in place to test fit, then use double sided tape or silicone glue to retain it in place.

  • Reminisce about the days when you use to knock chunks out your head on that sharp corner.........

description.text:
There are a lot of headphone stands out there, but I've yet to find a decent one that works well and properly with my AKG K7xx without putting stress on the bands or pads. This was custom designed in 3 parts that are PRESS FITTED together (can be glued together if you please), the bottom section is completely optional but that was designed to keep the pads from compressing each other over time. mine have gained a noticeable angle from them being compressed over time and thats what this stand was designed to prevent.

Like i said there are 3 parts.
the wall plate the extending rod
and the bottom section(optional)
there is also another extending rod that doesn't have the recess in it if you decide not to go with the lower section.

You can also print this with any infill you please. the one in the pictures has 10% but ill admit its a bit flimsy on the extending rod so id at least put that at 20 to 25%. the lower part should be around 25% as well though you can do 10% if you please. Be very careful inserting them into the slots after printing. the lower section is only .150in wide so it can snap easily if you bend it with low infill.

It is very important that your printer be calibrated and can produce accurate sized parts. I've included pictures of my machinists dial and what the tolerances of the gaps and rod should be. the extending rod is .4in x 1in. and the wall plate has a recess in it that is exactly .4in x 1in as well.The lower portion of the stand (optional) is .150in x 1in and so is the slot on the extending rod. so its extremely important that your printer is able to print extremely tight tolerances. My printer prints within .001 and its an extremely tight fit, but is possible to do without sanding.

You can use glue if you please but its honestly not necessary.

This is designed around the AKG K7xx so i assume it will fit with any k7 series headphones like the k712 and the 701 and 702..

Printer:

Full Custom Davinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10-100%

Notes:

you need at least a 7.5 inch wide bed to print the lower part of the stand. you may be able to get away with a smaller bed if you place it at an angle but i didn't try.

Can do any percentage of infill though i'd recommend no less than 25%

Have an accurate printer that prints near spot on tolerances.

comments.author: samxthomas

description.text:
My K8400 Printer from Vellemann does good work, but eventhough using BuildTak, printing ABS is a challenge. So I decided to install a heatbed

Material:

  • MK2B Headbed 214x214mm
    http://www.ebay.de/itm/Heizbett-MK2A-12V-PCB-schwarz-heated-bed-platform-build-printing-bed-RepRap-3D-/
  • Glass Plate 214x214x3mm
  • (extra) Aluminium Plate 214x214x3mm
  • Thermistor 100 kOhm
  • AWG14 power wires for heatbed 0.5m
  • AWG18 wires for therminstor 0.5m
  • heat shrink tube for isolating thermistor connections
  • thermal grease
  • 4 M3x15 screws with allen key head
  • 4 compression springs ID 3mm , 10mm long
    http://www.ebay.de/itm/4x-Druckfeder-5-x-7-x-1-mm-14-mm-lang-RepRap-3D-Drucker-Heizbett-Extruder-/
  • Female dupont socket connector 1x4, 1x2
  • 20 cm wide capton tape
    http://www.ebay.de/itm/200mm-Polyimide-Tape-Hitzebestandiges-Klebeband-Polyimid-Kapton-3D-Drucker-33m-/
  • Acetone
  • 4 clips
    http://www.ebay.de/itm/4xMaulklamme-51x20mm-Klemmweite-foldback-clamp-Stahlklammer-bulldog-clip-schwarz-

Instructions

  • Solder the AWG14 power wire to the heatbed
  • Solder the normal wire to the therminstor and isolate with a heat shrink tube.
  • Attach the thermistor to the center of the heatbed and them firm with a U shaped soldered wire
  • break off the 4 corners of the glass as a 2cm x 2cm triangle
  • stick capton tape smoothely onto the glass and clean with acetone
  • Unmount the Vertex Metal bed and remove the glass and the 4 holder clips
  • Offset (by 12 mm) 2 holes of the heatbead pcb such as the new holes do not short together when electrically connected by screws. Look at the sketch for that
  • Copy all 4 red holes (from sketch) of the heatbed onto the extra alu plate(4mm hole)
  • Mount the other to holes of the headbed to the rear clip holes of the vertex metal bed firmly
  • Now you can copy the offsetted heatbed hole positions to the vertex bed metalplate
  • Create 2 M3 threded holes in the front of the vertex bed metalplate (2.5mm drill diameter)
  • Sandwich the parts like: vertex bed, spring, heatbed, thermal grease, alu plate, 3mm shrink tube(insulator) , M3 screw
  • install the whole sandwich onto the z-stage again
  • Unplug and unmount the Z Endstop.
  • Offset the Mounting holes of the Z Endstop down by 10 mm. Best practice is to draw a template onto cardboard and mount the cardboard temporarily onto the rear wall.
  • Mount again the Z Endstop and make sure it does not collide with the Z Stage
  • Feed the two cables though the hole in the bottom
  • Cut the cables to correct length(make sure cables are long enough when z stage is in top position) and attach socket connectors
  • Connect the Sockets to the mainboard to "Bed Heater" ( pinout is + + - -) and Bed Therm(pinout is + -)
  • Put Glass onto extra metal plate and attach with clips
  • Test heatbed regulation function
  • Carefully level the new bed: Use screw on z stage, 3 vertex levelling screws from bottom, 4 allen key levelling screws on the top
  • Test autohome and make sure, the hotend does not run into the clips nor into the heatbed
  • Done

The Mk2A BRD File was copied from http://reprap.org to match content. Its not actually used

Since I enjoy making small designs by request... I am taking suggestions.

This tree topper was suggested by Cults3D.

Let me know what you would like me to design and I will share the files!

You should be able to print the model without support and since it's hollow, just put it on top of your tree.

I wanted to add a bearing at the top so I can eventually link the 2 z axis via 1 belt and use 1 motor. Once the belt arrives i will design a motor mount at the top to suite.

description.text:
This catapult was built using 1/4 inch MDF for the Lakehead Fall Design Competition.
It was cut using an Epilog Mini 24, 40 watt laser.
The bucket of the catapult was 3D printed out of PLA using a Dremel 3D20.

Design Overview

The catapult was designed to connect like a puzzle and have connections that require no form of fastening. The catapult can be assembled and reassembled easily. However to improve rigidity and durability, the use of wood glue is encouraged between all of the "slide in" connections.

Note: Dimensions of the AutoCad file are in inches. Dimensions of the .3ps file are in cm.

Torsion System

The catapult was designed to be powered by a torsion system. The material used by the creators was a type of fishing line that was fairly elastic. Overall, about 60 passes of the fishing line was made between the handles. Although fishing line worked well, there may be other materials available which will yield a greater power output.
In addition, two screws were used for the handles of the torsion system. These screws made it easy to increase or decrease the power of the catapult. It is important to note however, that the screws should settle in a position parallel to the base (horizontal) of the catapult to evenly distribute the force between both of the supports. If the screws are left perpendicular to the base (vertical), they tend to damage the section of MDF located between the two supports when the torsion material is subjected to high amounts of tension.
See below for a picture and video revealing how to wrap the material for a torsion catapult.
Video link: https://youtu.be/PRSBKm1encM

Image of how the torsion system should be set up. Video of how the torsion system should be set up: https://youtu.be/PRSBKm1encM Future Improvements

To improve the catapult design, the bucket attachment could have been made slightly larger than the dimensions of the catapult arm. This is due to the fact that the bucket was a very tight fit onto the arm.
Additionally, other materials could have been experimented with in order to improve the ability of the torsion system. The fishing line used was very timely to install and was fairly easy to snap if the handles were tightened too much.
Moreover, the bumper created to stop the arm could have been altered to better facilitate the angle at which the arm would hit it at. Upon prototyping, the bumper often would fall off since the arm had a tendency to hit it upwards (when the bumper was set up to stop the arm at a shallow angle).

References

"Catapult Physics." Real World Physics Problems. N.p., n.d. Web. 03 Dec. 2016. http://www.real-world-physics-problems.com/catapult-physics.html.

Credits to Matt Olinski

title: Theo Jansen Leg Mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Inspired by Theo Jansen's "Strandbeest", this is a leg mechanism of the sand walker. Be sure to check out the pictures and instructions I've included for how to assemble it. Inspiration: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HSKyHmjyrkA

Bill of Materials: 1 x 120
1 x 572
2 x 450
4 x 275
4 x 290
10 x 400
28 (ish) x link pin cap
Lots of links These should be, for the most part, able to snap together. There will be a bit of figuring out how to best put everything together, as far as layering and links goes, but that's the fun part! Note that the "120" piece is the "crank". The best way to get this to work is to place the "572" piece on the ground and work around that. "120" actually is 1.2", so keep that in mind when printing. Comments and suggestions are welcome. Keep in mind this is a work in progress...enjoy!

This is just my approach to prevent myself from eating to much sweets before christmas.
It's a crate, which opens only three times a day. This is realized by an ESP8266 (arduino with wifi) and a raspberry pi as webserver.
The webserver is checking against a database, wether I'm allowed to or not.
If you want more information, please check my blog:
https://flazer.com/blog/17/rfid-candy-box-twitter

comments.text:
Funny thing :-)
I see still a problem: One can take out too much when it is opened and the Software could have a backdoor ;-)
But the idea to learn about RFID by doing a project like these is great!
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text: Jeah. You are right. But there are rules! You have to accept them! One sweet per opening! But what backdoor do you mean?
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text:
Backdoor: You are using a WeMo mini D1 and I assume that it is connected somehow to a PC. So you could have implemented a secret key (routine, ...), that opens your box via WLAN ;-)
All I want to say is, you have to be strong against yourself, either with or without this box. But as a said, I like the project because of the idea behind it and the implementation :-)
comments.author: flazer

comments.text: Ah. Yeah. You are right. I'm the biggest problem and backdoor in this whole project. :/ I'm feeling bad. Thanks.
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text: Take a sweet ;-)

Yet another design I can't test until I get my 3d printer (paid for and waiting .....). Any advice is welcome.

If you compare the two wireframe mesh images you'll see one has many extra points. This model was made from combining two identicle models. The dyna version is the result of converting the model into a dyna mesh model in Zbrush, making the two models one. The dyna version has less detail, and might, and I'm guessing here, print better and faster by not having all those duplicate points.

description.text:
I corrected the dimensions of the STL files provided by andymark for a 3D printed string potentiometer.
Its in mm now.

The original STL files came from here:
http://www.andymark.com/product-p/am-2618.htm

I used a different 10-turn potentiometer, a AMM20B5A1CLASL380 that is contactless hall-effect sensor with rotation life 50 million shaft revolutions.
https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/bourns-inc/AMM20B5A1CLASL380/AMM20B5A1CLASL380-ND/3868206
But you can always use simple wirewound potentiometer like this one here:
https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/bourns-inc/3590S-2-103L/3590S-2-103L-ND/1088586

For the spring I used one from cheap ID badge holders like this one:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/10-x-ID-Card-Holder-Reel-Retractable-Badge-with-Belt-Clip-Ring-Pull-/371255688124

See a video of it in action:
https://youtu.be/3MMJfBPJwKc

A new video with better print and some tips here: https://youtu.be/NsgG6o2HFr4

Thanks
Thanos

Printer:

Wanhao i3 v2.2

No

Yes

0.2

30%

author: taylor1984

description.text:
While I've been building a reprap huxley machine, I had a problem where only one of my z motors moved. This caused the x-axis mounts to break. Since I was going to have to reprint them anyway, I figured I would make the design a little stronger too.

I'm new at 3d modeling for printing (I'm more used to animation), so these models could use a bit of tidying up. It is just small overhangs and clips though, so that shouldn't affect the strength of the part, and might not even show up unless you have a pretty high resolution.

I recommend printing in ABS because it's stronger, and with a decent infill, maybe 40%.

title: RepRapGuru Prusa I3 V2 Cooling Fan Mount

description.text:
Rotate 90* to print from base- no need for supports or raft

Why bother hooking up two fans when one works just fine? Not too much air to cause bed heating issues, enough air to keep your pla prints clean and solid.

This is a cooling fan duct designed to work with my RepRapGuru Prusa I3. Take out the bolts that hold the extruder heatsink on and rebuild from the motor-2 washers-extruder housing- black heatsink- cooling duct- spacer (already on the bolt).

While you have this apart it is a good time to tighten any loose internal bolts that may not have been torqued down from the factory.

Printer:

Reprapguru Prusa i3 v2

Resolution:

High Res

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Mine worked fine with PLA. .1mm layer height and 100% infill. Just need to source a bolt to hold the fan to the duct (or just glue on)

comments.text: This print held me over until i figured out how to attach a separate blower fan.  While this design worked to cool a bit, having a dedicated blower has drastically improved my print quality.  The reprapguru is a great printer and i've enjoyed printing out many upgrades.

author: jmcgall1

description.text:
I couldn't find a decent 2 into 1 Y Splitter that uses PC4-M6 Couplers, so I knocked this up.

All you need is 3 PC4-M6 Pneumatic Couplers and 50mm of Bowden Tube to go from the coupler to the hot end.

Note: This does not work well with PLA. PETG and Copolymers work without issue

Update 1: reduced in size, tightened up holes for Pneumatic Couplers
Update 2: Further reduction in size reduced filament path holes, refinement of Tool change script
Update 3: Fixed error in model
Update 4: Updated GCode - G4 is the key to get it working reliably

Tool Change Script - Simplify3D

G91; Relative Coordinates
G1 Z+1 F420;  Lift Z for Tool Change
G1 X50 Y50 F4800; Move X Y for tool change
G90; Absolute Coordinates
T[old_tool]; Select Old Tool
G92 E0; Zero Extruder
G91; Relative Coordinates
G1 E-5 F10000; Fast Retract 5mm
G1 E2 F10000; Fast Reinsert 2mm
G1 E-47 F10000; Fast Retract 47mm
G4 P3000; Pause 3secs
G1 E-60 F1000; Fast long retract
G90; Absolute Coordinates
G92 E0; Zero Extruder
T[new_tool]; Select New tool
G92 E0; Zero Extruder
G91; Relative Coordinates
G1 E105 F10000; Fast insert 105mm
G1 E5 F300; 5mm/s Feed 5mm
G92 E0; Zero Extruder
G1 Z-1 F420; Return Z to resume printing
G90; Absolute Coordinates

Tool change Retraction in S3D is set to 6mm with a 2.5mm extra restart distance at 100mm/s

FB2020 CoreXY

I'm guessing that the distances need to be tweaked for a volcano hot end, since the heat block is longer. Do you have any tips on how I might determine a good starting point for those distances? Thanks for any help.
comments.author: karltinsly

comments.text: The Retract/reinsert/retract/pause is critical with these. Easiest way to discern the length is to extrude then pull the bowden tube, measure the length from the end of the tube to the end of the filament. You then need to make sure that you pause within the heat sink to cool the filament. You can then retract fully.

title: Robo 3D EZStruder carriage with part cooling fan mount

description.text:
Replacement X-Carriage for Robo 3D that supports EZStruder and E3D hot end.  
Update: Fixed files to use the zip tie mounting method that doesn't require disassembling the entire printer and also increased the strength of the belt housing because mine broke after about 6 months.

This carriage is setup for Pico or E3D hot ends. The removal of the press fit and replacement with zip tie mounting dramatically simplifies assembly and removes alignment problems with the press fit. There are holes on the front side for mounting of a part cooling fan. I have only designed the cooling fan for a Pico hot end as that is what I'm using these days. I designed this with my mediocre CAD skills in Fusion 3D. Printing:
  • Use ABS.
  • I printed with 15% infill. My gut says this is OK but it wouldn't hurt to bump it to 25%
  • Support is required. I printed with the front facing down.
  • I recommend an acetone vapor bath but this should be fine without.
  • The end stop switch screw is an M3 screw
  • The bearings are LM8UU.
  • You lose about 15mm of X width with this carriage.
  • Someone willing to run with this design might be able to recover my lost 15mm with more clever packaging.
  • Extruder pulses/mm is 92.6
    • E3D: http://e3d-online.com/E3D-V5-1.75mm-Direct-All-Metal-HotEnd
    EZStruder: http://seemecnc.com/collections/parts-accesories/products/copy-of-ezstruder-cold-end-kit
    Robo 3D: http://www.robo3dprinter.com/

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/el8UWk1fY2i

A group challenge print. Other members were Emily T and Teresa. The design was created on Fusion360.
The handle is only hollow at the top to have the broken piece slide in. The rest of the handle is solid. Once it printed and we placed the broken piece in, we used the heat tool to mold it onto the teaspoon.
A small clip that can be attached to a coat hanger to form a simple tie holder!

Print as many of the clips as you need - I can fit 5 on the long edge of a cheap plastic coat hanger - then attach them with glue (I used superglue). Getting the right infill in the clips is critical; I got the best result with a pattern that had ~5mm spacing between the elements, but you may be able to get away with multiple walls instead.
The plastic is springy enough to pinch the ties and hold them in place so they won't fall off as the hanger gets jostled about in your closet.

author: jasim

description.text:
######### Update 1: #########

Updaten Software files in MnM_ActionCamSlider_Software.zip

Changelog App:
1.1

  • Added App Icon
  • changed max time in [h] from 60 to 24
  • setting time in [h] now with minutes
  • Angle now ranges from -180 to + 180°

Changelog Scetch:

  • More Comments
  • Changed Steps/rev to DRV8834

Added Wiring Diagram

########################

This is my GoPro compatible Action Cam Slider Project.
It's main goal is to make an easy, cheap slider for timelapses.
This slider can take up to ~10^38 sec for the distance... should be slow enough xD
Fastest Speed is 500 Steps/Sec => 1 Revolution in 4 Sec => 20mm/sec (at 26mm wheels)

######### HARDWARE #########

There are two Versions:

3D-Printed [PV]: Just print all the parts.
Non-Printed [NV]: Print the ActionCamSlider_Plans.pdf in 100% scale, glue it to a sheat of your favourite material and cut along the Lines

For all Versions;
2x M8 Screws (25mm for PV, 30-35mm for NV)
6-8x M3x10mm (8 if you do not glue the TopMotor Mount to the Base)
1x M5x15mm
1x 10mm tension spring or a rubber band
2x 608zz (Skateboard) Ball Bearing

For NV:
2-X M8 Nuts (depends on wanted hight and material)
2x 20mm Spacer (with M3 Thread)

Electronics (Linked parts on eBay [affiliated]):
1x Arduino Nano (or compatible)
https://goo.gl/6Ux23S
1x HC-05 Bluetooth Module
https://goo.gl/X27cM0
2x 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motors
https://goo.gl/TDYjsP
2x Stepper motor drivers. Best would be to use DRV8824 or DRV8834 https://goo.gl/Bni40L
Both can drive low voltage Stepper motors but they are relativly expancive (~10$).
That way you could run everything from a power bank.
If you have some A4988 laying around you can also use these, but than you have to supply >8V and step it down to 5V for the arduino and Bluetooth with this converter https://goo.gl/sWpdlK for example.

######### SOFTWARE #########
(all in MnM_ActionCamSlider_Software.zip)

Arduino:
Custem settings (e.g. Wheel Diameter) are set in the Top of the Scetch
Upload the Arduino Scetch to the Arduino

Smartphone (App Android only, workaround for iOS):
The App was made using the free "MIT App Inventer 2"
You can just download the APK and install it (allow Unknown sources under Settings>Security)
If you want to have a look at the Code or don't trust me (;P) create an App Inventor account and import the .aia-file.
Pair the HC-05 and your Smartphone before connecting the App to the slider or it will not show up.

iOS:
You can use a Bluetooth Terminal app like BluTerm to control the Slider.
Just send the commands explaned in the following protocol.

######### PROTOCOL #########
The protocol is pretty basic but easy to extend. The commands ALWAYS have the pattern: #;#;#;#.
The first digit (at the moment)can be 0 (=Set) or 1 (=Move)
For now you can only set the wheel diameter (diameter on that it is running). Default is 26mm

To set 30mm wheel diameter: 0;30;0;0. (Canges are NOT stored in EEPROM at the moment!)

Moving: 1;TimeForTheMove;Distance;TiltCamAngle
Example: 1;20;100;30. The move will take 20 sec, along 100mm (left to right) and tilt the cam 30°
You can use negative Values for Way and Tilt to move into the other direction
If you set Time to 0 it will move as fast as possible.

######### MORE INFO #########
For more infos see the Project-Videos
Part1: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jT-A2rkLJT4
Part2: https://youtu.be/9_ftOecn1go

Musik used in Video:
Tours - Enthusiast http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Tours/Enthusiast/Tours_-_Enthusiast

title: Gopro Session Cage with lug at the back

description.text: On my last skydive of the season, my original gopro housing broke while hitting the plane's housing. This was made from the best gopro housing I've found here. I modified it to have the lug at the back instead of underneath the housing to immitade the original gopro housing design. My gopro session is mounted on my helmet at the chin level so I needed to have the same angle of the housing when attached to it mount.

This way the back of the housing will be rough but it is the less important surface of the design to my opinion. A little bit of sanding with dremmel solved the issue in no time. It is more important to have the interior of the housing smooth and precise to hold the camera correctly.

Added larger opening at the back

I originally printed a version with only 2 wholes at the back but it was so hard to remove the camera from the housing that I decided to enlarge the back opening (again by immitating the original housing) but I did not print the final version.

Tinkercad first try

I am a complete noob so this was designed using only thinkercad web application to modify the original source taken here. Thanks to the original author. Printed at 0.1mm precison, the small cut imperfections from the tinkercad cut & pastes are not apparent.

title: Arduino mounting plate for Bitbeam (LEGO Technic compatible)

description.text:
This is a laser cuttable mounting plate for attaching an Arduino to your LEGO Technic or Bitbeam creations. Source home: https://github.com/hugs/bitbeam
Project home: http://bitbeam.org/

1) Buy 1/8 inch thick basswood from an art supply or hobby store 2) a) Download bitbeam-arduino-plate.dxf and lasercut it!
b) Download bitbeam-arduino-plate.scad, modify it in OpenSCAD, export to DXF... then lasercut it! 3) Use three 1/2 inch long, 4-40 steel machine hex screws and nuts to attach your Arduino to the plate. 4) Write a comment here saying you've completed steps 1, 2, and 3!

title: Portable DVR with Belt Clip for HMDVR

description.text:
Bought an HMDVR and was really impressed with how it worked but trying to use it was a major pain in the butt. I had wires everywhere!!!

So I came up with this.

It's like a Walkman, you hang it on your belt, and it's got a spot to put your battery so it's not just hanging and an XT-60 right on top to plug in.

There are a couple of switches on the front to control power and signal.
I used a SPST switch so I could turn it on and off without having to unplug the battery every time I was done recording.

And I used a SPDT switch so that I can use both the video in and the video out with just the flick of the switch. Before I had to swap cables.

I have Fatsharks and if I want the view the recording I flip the switch down and then flip the little switch on the bottom left side of my goggles that turns off the video receiver, then I can see the HMDVR video feed. Go into setting, view videos, delete videos, all kinds of things!

The HMDVR fits loosely in the slot so I put a piece of Velcro (the soft half, not the hook side) behind it, which made it fit like a glove, but I can still get it out if I would need to.

I printed all 3 parts in ABS. Drilled the holes for the switches and one for the Video cable that goes to my goggles. Wired it up, I have a 5 volt UBEC inside the cavity to step down the Lipo battery to the 5 volts the HMDVR wants.

Then I used Acetone to "Glue" or "Fuse" the Parts together.

This thing is really sweet! It really makes that HMDVR a joy to use. Before it was too much of a pain and I would generally skip it because I didn't want to deal with it. Very proud of this project!

Printer:

Hacked Davinci with E3D

description.text:
With cooler weather, the butter won't just melt on the counter, and I like to leave it out. So I made a covered dish. The hinged lid is convenient. The little triangle thing is to wipe excess butter off the knife.

The dish fits a standard (?) 4 ounce butter cube, roughly 1.5 x 1.5 x 3.25 inches.

Bottom section, 80 minutes, 45g ABS. Top 100 min 50g using Afinia defaults (0.3mm Z, medium speed with a raft).
Metric files included.

ABS is plenty flexible enough to slide the top onto the hinge-pins. I wouldn't know about PLA... probably will be OK.

title: LCD 12864 Graphic Smart Display Controller Holder for 8020 T-Slot Aluminum Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: See this thing for a variation of this display mount that hangs the LCD display vertically from the extruded aluminum, and allows the Arduino and RAMPS to be mounted directly to the backplate.

This is a display holder for the LCD 12864 Graphic Smart Display Controller for 3D printers. Mine came with this electronics kit, however you can purchase this display as a standalone LCD monitor. I made it to attach at a 45 degree angle onto 25mm 8020 T-Slot Extruded Aluminum.

Hardware Needed

  • 4 M3x25 screws (I only had 3 in my pictures)

  • 4 M3 washers and nuts

  • 2 each M6 bolts, washers, and T-Nuts for your aluminum extrusion. I used 12mm bolts but your desired length may vary depending on your T-Slot.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print 'LCD Face' in face down orientation. If your bed adhesion is strong be careful removing it. Recommend pulling it up from the face directly attached to the bed and not by the angled overhang.

Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360.

Thanks to thing:855134 for sharing the stl model of the display pcb which helped me design this case.

comments.text: Depending on the size I guess. If it's 25mm wide (my bolt holes are centered at 12.5mm) then yes. My M6 bolts are 12 mm long, but I suppose you can use any size bolts you want. If Openbuilds pieces are 20mm wide, then this design would still attach but float 2.5mm above the rail, instead of sitting on it. If it was 30mm wide, then my bolt holes would not be centered and it wouldn't fit. I haven't used Open builds except for the wheel rails (which fits my 25mm 8020 extruded pieces) so I think it should work but am not positive. Download the parts into cad and download the open builds parts into cad and see how things line up if you are still concerned.

description.text:
An updated ver will be added in next few days
Changes will be made to top part only, with thicker motor mount and added hinged mount for a 40mm motor cooling fan with block supports.

Direct Drive Chimera or Cyclops mount with radial fan part cooling

Use 5 mm threads plastic screws to assemble bottom and top together ( I used screws that I recycled from taking apart old TV's they are the black screws that normally hold the back covers).Use either M5 or 10/24 screws to attach the hotend mount to X carriage there is no nut trap as the screws bite firmly in to the plastic. if you have a problem I could add one.

I design to use with MK8 direct drive motors cold end found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:111711.
My E step at 1/16 micro stepping is 157.01
The X carriage and radial fan duct was made by Prusa research, I only modified it to fit my screws.

comments.text: Hi jartz, It prints like a champ, Zero issues with everything from pla to ninja flex and all taulman nylons, the Ptfe tubes are really not in a bad enough angle that it causes any issues the filament, pushes right down to the hot end with out a problem. Honestly I tried many Chimera dual extruders that others had designed , and they just didn't seem to work right for ever thing or the took up to much space that I lost some printing space on the X axis or it was a fight to change filaments , which is way I designed this one,    I been using since last November and I couldn't be happier.

title: Springy pen holder for 3D printer / CNC, with software

description.text:
This is a pen (or maybe drag-knife (untested)) holder for attaching to a 3D printer head or a CNC (untested). The holder is springy (changing the spring thickness will change just how springy) and highly customizable. It's designed to be moderately low profile to give more drawing space.

You will need some sort of a tool-clip for attaching this to your print head / CNC. I use this one to attach to my XYZ DaVinci 1.0a. The SCAD file will generate holes for M3 screws to attach to the tool-clip. You'll also have to by default drill through the holes for M3 screws for holding the pen (or other tool), as there is a mini-support platform there.

The default pen size is up to 15mm, but you can resize that.

Changing the "wave fraction" from 0.5 to 1 gives you a longer section of a sine wave for the springs.

You can use my gcodeplot.py python script to convert SVG path-only files (just load an arbitrary SVG file into Inkscape, Select All, Object|Object-to-Path, and save) to gcode for this (I've only tested this on a 3D printer -- no idea if it'll work with CNC). I suggest editing gcodeplot.py to change the xyMin (lowest device coordinates for drawing area), xyMax (highest ones), penDownZ (z-coordinate for drawing), penUpZ (z-coordinate for moving) and safeUpZ (z-coordinate for parking) parameters at the top of the Plotter class to match your printer.

Once you have a path-only SVG file, you can do:
python gcodeplot.py filename.svg > filename.gcode

Then send the gcode file with your usual printer control utility (I use Repetier Host). You can also send the gcode directly to the printer with:
python gcodeplot.py --send=portname filename.svg
(On my Windows system, COM3 or COM4 works as the portname; you will also need to install pyserial, e.g., with pip install pyserial.)

By default colors are shaded with parallel lines according to intensity. In theory, though I haven't tested it yet, you can use the script to switch pens for different colors, by using a pen description file.

The Hello Kitty was taken from here and drawn directly on a sticky note stuck on the print bed. Ideally, the other end would be stuck down with painter's tape, but I didn't bother (and it only resulted in a slight shift in shading in one area).

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0a with Repetier

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

27% Set

Notes:

Printed in ABS and used a brim to avoid warping at corners.
On my printer, the nut holes aren't big enough unless I add a tolerance of 0.5mm to them. If they aren't big enough, one can still tighten a screw to pull a nut into the hole.

remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini X Gantry Support + Camera Mount [Reinforced and Realigned]

description.text:
The original bracket was very nice, but it is not very solidly attached, due to all the attachment screws being on a single side of the stress point.

So I added a bit more material to mount to a hole on the other side as well.

Edit:
I added two more files to support additional bracing at the top. In the pictures you can see these parts in black. The vertical only bracing was not stiff enough for my taste. Both rods are 6mm. The screws I used are M3x0.5x13mm.

On my printer the holes printed slightly undersized, so I opened them up with a 6mm drill to create a slight press fit. If the rods are not some sort of press fit after you print the parts, I suggest to take up the extra space with some epoxy or some such.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1750 mm

Infill:

20%
The original already had a gap from the getgo and wiggled easily.

author: redhair

title: Anet A6 LCD Screen Cover for Overnight Printing

description.text:
This slip-on LCD Screen Cover allows you to print overnight without the blinding effects of the Anet A6 screen illuminating the entire room (this has not been tested on an A8, although I am sure it can be modified to fit). This was a problem for me because, due to the limited space of my 3-person apartment, my printer is housed in my bedroom.

I have included two models: a blank cover and a cover embossed with my initials for concept proof. Feel free to download the .ipt or .step files and upload a remix as you wish. Just please remember to attribute. I'd love to see the awesome designs that could come out of this.

When using 15% infill, a slight amount of light allows the cover to have a subtle glow. This gives a pretty neat lithophane effect. The amount of light that shows through can obviously be altered by increasing infill or using a darker color filament, although the setup in which I printed doesn't allow enough light through to even notice.

For printing with no supports and optimal light blocking, position the cover upside down on the print bed as shown in the photos. This orients the grid infill parallel to the screen and perpendicular to the emitted light.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15% Grid

Fitting Adjustment

The tolerances on the depth of the overhang allow for several different positions of the screen, as others' screens may be in a different position as mine. If the cover fits loosely, crafting felt or adhesive-backed foam pads can be added to the back surface (see attached photo). If the cover is too tight, the two sides can be filed or sanded to fit.

Crafting Felt for fitment added with Scotch Tape

Using the following options:

the_word = Shep
border = 2
$fn = 75

This worked for me, have no idea if it will work for anyone else. For all I know it might break your build plate in half or do something equally awful. I had to fix a jam during this process because my warpage was so amazingly great that it wrapped about a foot of filament all around the inside of my extruder. You have been warned!

My acrylic build plate had warped over the years. So I tried standing on it to straiten it out and snapped it in half. With the makerware software I could make a good print using a raft. But when I switched to cura on octopi the raft was stuck hard to the prints. I tried putting packing tape down on top of the raft and that did work.

Then I had a thought. Why not print a raft just once covering the entire build plate, permanently attached to the surface of my broken build plate? Then I could print anything and it would come right off. And it worked!

Just clean your build plate and level it as well as you can. Then print the thin8.stl onto the plate with no raft. If your warpage is really bad you might want to try printing a few smaller shapes in the center or around the outside edge depending on your warpage to get the plate in the ballpark so that this will even work. Try to get it to stick as well as you can because ideally it will be the level surface you print on here on out. The first few layers might not evenly cover, because of build plate warpage. And I had to clear out a filament jam in the extruder motor section because of how much my plate was warped up on each corner.

Once the build of the new surface was complete, I covered the surface with packing tape, overlapping it slightly. I put glue stick down on this, lightly, mixed it with a few drops of water and made sure it covered the area where I am going to print. You also have to move the bed down a bit because this new surface is higher than the old surface, by loosening the thumb screws under the bed, and then just move the head around and use the thumb screws and your eyeball to get the tip of the nozzle just to the surface of the bed. Turning the thumb screws left lowers the bed, turning right raises the bed.

I print with a couple of brims and manually adjust the thumb screws as the brim is being laid down making sure that the filament is flat, not round, but not too flat. The brim should be even clear around the print.

My prints now come out with a shiny surface where it was against the packing tape and they just pull off by hand with just a bit of effort.

When I was able to just pull the print off by hand with just a little tug, I almost cried because of the trauma I have endured over the years stabbing myself with razors and putty knives trying to remove prints.

description.text:
Looking for a high poly low detail head to use as a base for a sculpting project. Found a good low poly start from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455885 and took it from there.

First I removed all the co-planer triangles in the STL file to make it easier to manipulate the file and fixed some non-coplaner areas on the base. Next I fixed his nose and gave him a right nostril. Then I quadrupled the poly count with a smooth quad tool to create natural curves and enhance the details and smoothed the model two levels to achieve a smooth muscled surface.

Very pleased with the result.

Cura scaled and oriented for printing. Use a wide brim and supports everywhere.

The STL file is now the updated one with the perfectly smooth base with no smoothing wrapped around one edge.

Printer:

Rigidbot 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I turned on a 12 line brim to help stick the print to the bed. Set support for 60.80 degrees and turn on everywhere to support his ears and to minimize where the supports show up. The only place they are actually needed are under his ears. Under his chin and the back of his head don't need them at all.

I wanted a hand spinner but I was looking for a much smoother surface than the standard 3D printed ones. Acrylic seemed the best fit but there aren't many templates out there for a laser cut spinner. Converting from STL to SVG with Slic3r leaves a few uneven edges that detracted from the smooth edges I was looking for. So I made my own.

All four of the holes in this are just slightly smaller than 22mm. With the kerf of the laser a 608 bearing snaps in without needing any glue. The picture shows it with a single bearing in the middle but you can easily add three more.

This is two 1/8" pieces of acrylic glued together since that's what I had lying around. If you have 1/4" material you can avoid the gluing. I hit the outside of it with a torch to give it a nice smooth beveled edge (and burnt it in one spot .)

EDIT - I've added a new file that has acrylic posts and grips. The posts are in middle of what was waste material. Cut the 8mm posts from 1/8" acrylic and glue them to the two discs and just press them into both sides of the spinner. They should snap in and stay without any glue.

EDIT - Added the smaller spinner design. This again has a post and some grips.

description.text:
This is a cover for a 12V 30A PSU that integrates a regular PC cord and a power switch. I am upgrading the power supply for my Anet A8 printer and I needed a cover and could not find anything I liked. The wiring may be a little tight, but I do not believe it will be any worse than some of the others, like the one I am using for my stock 20A PSU.

you will need 3 M4 screws to screw the cover onto the PSU and 2 M3 screws and nuts to attach the IEC Socket.

Power switch - http://www.ebay.com/itm/3pcs-Red-Pilot-Light-Heavy-Duty-110V-120V-AC-ON-OFF-Locking-ROCKER-SWITCH-R13C-/300720027395

I used one I had on hand, but that one should work. I also used a male plug I had purchased at my local electronics store but the one below should work.

IEC Socket - http://www.ebay.com/itm/10-Pcs-Black-3-Pins-IEC320-C14-Inlet-Power-Plug-Socket-AC-250V-10A-/252183083124

Power Supply - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HPW00QY

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

This needs to be printed with the grill side down. It should automatically load into your slicer in the correct orientation, so there should be no need to rotate it.

author: tmenet

title: Reinforced Prusa i3 MK2 Y axis motor mount with end stop mount

description.text:
update - I had moved the holes for the end stop back by 1mm in my original design because I needed to for my printer until I learned I could adjust it by the nuts on the 10mm rods. I had forgotten about that change when uploading the last version. V3 has the location of those back to the position of the original design.
------

After dropping a spool on the original and breaking it, gluing it back together, and dropping the same spool twice more on it, I decided to make a new one.

The original bothered me from the initial build because the belt tension caused the motor to skew on the two screw mount points. The design needed either a third support in the back like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:406473 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372192 or a stronger part with at least three screw connections.

There are a few remakes out there for the i3, but I didn't find any for the MK2 with the endstop mount. So I made this one.

It's a total remake with none of the original design. But other than being about twice as thick, it's an exact fit for all the screw holes, the placement of the endstop, the space for the belt and everything else. I based the new thickness on the x-axis mount at 17m.

I've changed it a bit since uploading a few days ago. I've removed the dependency on rounded_box and made the cutout that was on the bottom more printable by giving it a gentle overhang that should print without support now.

Instructions

You will need one additional screw (M3 10mm I think), which is probably in your spares.

I printed it in ABS with about 50% infill to be rock solid and it's been working perfectly on my i3 MK2. 20% or 30% would probably be ok with 1.5mm or better perimeter and 0.9mm face thickness. Thicker layer height makes for strong parts with better layer adhesion. I did 0.3mm layer height.

You should not need to cut any zip ties, and will only need to loosen the minimum number of nuts to get the replacement done. Probably will take less than 30 minutes if you follow carefully (and I didn't forget anything)

To install:

  1. Remove the endstop
  2. Place printer on it's side so the power supply is flat on a table.
  3. Remove the bottom screw from the Y motor and then the top screw to remove the motor
  4. Unscrew the 2 M10 (larger) nuts from the back
  5. Loosen the 4 M8 (smaller) nuts from the corner brackets but don't remove them

  6. Pull the two M8 rod assembly off the M10 rods, leaving the smooth rods with the rest of the printer

  7. On one side only, finger tighten the M8 screws again and then count the number of turns to unscrew them until they are flush with the end of the threaded rod. Note that count for both nuts and then remove them.
  8. Pull off the corner bracket, the nuts and washers that are in the way, and the old motor mount, leaving the second set of nuts and washers that is supporting the other side of the motor mount unmoved.
  9. Put the new part on in the same place and screw it tight
  10. Put the nuts and washers on with plenty of room to slide the end bracket back on.
  11. Put the last of the M8 washers and nuts on until flush with the end of the threaded rod
  12. Count the turns to tighten to exactly the same place they were at when you took them off
  13. Slide the M8 assembly back onto the M10 rods with the smooth rods back in place under the zip ties
  14. Put the M10 washers and nuts back on and finger tighten only, but make sure all the gap is removed, especially on the power supply side.
  15. Tighten the inside M8 nuts and washers against the corner bracket all the way, leaving the outside ones exactly where you put them.
  16. Tighten all the nuts all the way.
  17. Align the motor and end stop so that the wires are to the back and under the mount like they probably were before
  18. Screw in the bottom rear motor mounting screw (closest to the bottom M8 rod), not too tight.
  19. Put the belt over the pulley and add the other two screws to the motor mount and tighten all the way, making sure the belt doesn't get too tight and break the other mounts.
  20. Secure the end stop on its mount with the wires routed properly
  21. Since it's not getting skewed anymore, the belt might be tighter, check for proper tensioning and adjust the nuts at the front of the system as needed so as not to change the end stop position.
  22. Put it back on it's feet and test

If you are like me, you may want to make some better spool holders next.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

50%

The design is mostly based on using cylinders and hull to join them together to make the shapes and cutouts.

This is quite easy to do since most of the cylinders used to make the holes will share the exact same center point as the ones used to make the outside shape, but with a bigger radius.

The file could be parameterized to make it more readable, but since it's a one-off design, there should be any customization needed, so I didn't find it worth the trouble to clean it up that much.

title: Ultra-Light Micro FPV Quad Racer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A low budget First Person View micro size Quadcopter, which I hope to someday race against others. There are 2 versions of the UL frame; A conversion frame for 4mm square arm gearbox quads like Vivitar Air Defender & WLToys UFO and a direct drive version with snap-in motor mounts (7.5mm). The FC platform is 36 x 40mm. If using 5" props you will need to either replace all the props with 4" or modify the rear props, I will test both methods. You can use tape, a velcro strap, a thick rubber band or an o-ring to secure the battery and wifi cam (if using FPV) to the platform using the tabs on the sides. I may add LED holes, a snazzy top cover, useless prop guards & battery tray at some point, if there is enough interest. I will be designing/building this as I go, so make sure and check back often for updated files.

Update! - I added the battery tray & component deck to the design and slightly adjusted the rear motor arm angles for the direct drive chassis, as well as lightening the whole load some.
So no need to mod props or change to different size now!. I made separate files for the extra components and some parts will require some trimming to fit..

Update 2! - I mocked everything together and it looks like it will fly even ;) I may have to use rubber foam insulation around the battery and just stuff it in on top of the cam, we shall see. I cant wait to see what the 16mp wifi cam sees when its flying.

Printer:

My H-bot Dual on Mega/RAMPS 1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used a 4mm brim & supports where needed on the battery tray mounting holes.

This badge is for the Generation 1 Ford Expedition. The only thing about it that designates it as "For an Expedition" is the hole placements for the pins.

The pins are separate files (you may need to adjust the diameters depending on your print settings.

Printer:

Modified Monoprice MakerSelect v1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.06mm

Infill:

40-100%

Notes:

Many vehicles do not have a need for pins, you can easily close the pin holes and apply adhesive tape to the back and stick to your vehicle.

I recommend 3M double-sided foam tape, the kind with red backing found in rolls, for any car exterior application.

Design Specifics

I originally designed this so that the first 3.5mm of material was glow-in-the-dark, then by switching the upper 2.5mm to car color matched ABS it created a spooky back-lit effect that was perfect for the Anon Stigma.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 IKEA JANSJÖ Bottom Mount

description.text:
This is a bracket to mount the IKEA JANSJÖ LED work lamp to the bottom front of your Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus X/Z axis uprights. I measured this off an Monoprice Maker Select Plus and am unsure if it fits the regular Maker Select or Duplicator i3.
I modified the Duplicator i3 Lamp Mount by Drazen concept by moving it to the bottom of the printer. I did this because I could not mount my lights to the top since I mounted a Raspberry Pi for Octoprint on one side, and a tool holder on the other.
To install:
1- Remove the outermost two M3x5mm bolts.
2- Attach bracket using M3x10mm (or longer) bolts
3- Insert IKEA JANSJÖ LED lamp. The clearance is very close on the bottom bolt, but it should fit with a little effort.
4- Screw the bolts supplied with the IKEA JANSJÖ LED lamp into the bottom of the bracket.

If you are running your printer off a SD card and not OctoPrint, I would recommend you rename the gcode file you generate so that it does not have a Ö character in it. It might crash your printer.

Printer:

MonoPrice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%, less is probably fine.
Modeled in Solidworks

title: Invisible 2.5 Inch Hard Drive Wall Mount

description.text: This is a wall mount for 2.5 Inch hard drives and SSD. The drive mount attaches to the back of the drive and is not visible from the front. Attach the wall mount (threaded whole facing up) and simply slip the drive over the mount. Gravity will hold it there, but you can optional add a #6-32 screw to keep it in place. I've printed this in PLA using .1 layer heights and the threads work surprisingly well even though they were printed horizontally.

title: LEA Bicycle Light (Low Energy Automatic)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
LEA Bicycle lights aims to solve the problem of bicycle crash by cars over the world.
One of the most common causes of bicycle accidents is caused by the low visibility of those vehicles at night.
Lot of people don't have a rear light because they don't want to care about switching it on, replacing the battery,weather conditions, getting their light robbed,etc.

LEA tries to solve those problems with an low cost design of a automatic long battery duration Fab Lab fabricable device.

Using an ATtiny 45,light sensor and vibration switch. LEA automatically switch on only with low light conditions ( shadow areas, night,etc) and feels that the bicycle is in movement. The rest of the time the device automatically stay in sleep mode to save battery, only waking up to check for light or movement.

Using a simple case design the project can be replicated with a very simple and low amount of components pcb, two aa batteries and 3d printed/lasercutter or cnc parts(a possible aluminium case is available)

The bike holder is completely 3dprinted an only need a 3-4mm screw and bolt to hold it in place.
The electronic container can be 3d printed or cnc in one unique piece of aluminium with a 3 axis cnc. Both part are holded together by pressure but two holes for 3mm screws are available to secure everything properly.
The battery should last 3-5 months on a normal daily use ( using the bicycle on a two way run to work for 20 min each time)

B.O.M
ATtiny45
Phototransistor OP580DA
Capacitor 22uf
Resistor 1M
Resistor 10k
Vibrator Switch
LED SMD 5050
All the components are fab inventory standart except for the vibrator switch and the AAbattery Holders

Designed and fabricated by Eduardo Chamorro
Fab Lab Seoul http://fablab-seoul.org/
https://vimeo.com/193660039

comments.text: Would it be a bad idea to vacuum form with ABS sheet over a PLA printed part?
comments.author: markyoe

comments.text: It would be a very bad idea. Your PLA part will deform as soon as the hot ABS touches it, specially under vacuum. I actually tried it before i CNCed my wooden mould.

title: Laser Cut Christmas Tree Decoration - Ball-shape Ornament

description.text:
This ball-shaped Christmas ornament is symmetric in design. For the first pass, engrave and cut. Remove the cut-out and flip the piece and insert back into the remain acrylic sheet.

For the second pass, just engrave only.

You can hang this ball-shaped Christmas ornament on your Christmas tree using a piece of string, paper clip or whathaveyou.

Either way, enjoy!

The Christmas vector images is NOT created by me. You can mix-n-match the images and make your own unique ball-shaped ornament.

The original sources:
a) http://www.freepik.com/free-vector/beautiful-cards-merry-christmas-of-tree-and-ball_910747.htm

description.text:
Convenient little yoyo accessory I made when I got my new yoyo and had so much fun with it that I needed something to protect my finger from the string cutting into it, I didn't have any yoyo gloves or thin regular gloves so I quickly made this.

Middle diameter is 17mm (0.67 inches).
Scale it up or down depending on how big your finger is.

Loop the sting of the yoyo you would normally put your finger through, in the grove on the ring.
